Dear Anti-Religion People
 
 What do you hope to accomplish by bashing religion? 

 Labeling someone as "anti-religion" or calling it bashing implies there is mindless criticism that has no merit, or criticism for its own sake. That is not taking place. 
 
 
What constructive activity do you hope to do by getting on here and saying how wrong religion is? 

 Um, this is an opinion forum and a religion thread on that forum. If someone raises an issue and my honest response happens to be a criticism of religion, that is the constructive activity. 
 
 
 
Doesn't the first amendment matter anymore? 

 Yes, of course it does. And that includes the right to speak openly and honestly about religion. Is discussion of religion off-base to you?
 
 
Why do you say we're evil? 
 
 I don't believe anyone has said that. 
 I do not have any sweeping generalizations about any religious person. I have some specific criticisms against you as a person because you refuse to debate logically and mindfully. Evidence of that is this post itself, which contains numerous misunderstandings and mischaracterizations. 
 
 
What is wrong with belief?

 Belief? Nothing. 
 Faith? If defined as the belief in something for which there is no evidence or despite evidence to the contrary, that is a very stupid thing, indeed. 
 
 
What is wrong with faith in heaven? 

 See "faith" above. 
 There is no heaven.
 
 
 
Your intent is only to put down others. 
 
 Completely untrue.
 My intent to express my opinion about the lunacy of religion.
 
 
 
Why do you think you're being smart just by implying that God is evil? 

 No one thinks they are "being smart".
 No one has implied God is evil. A non-existent being has no attributes.
 The mythical god of the bible does some pretty nasty stuff, however.
 
 
Do you think it's funny? 

 Nope.
 I think you are.
 
 
 
Do you need a way to vent your anger? 

 No anger to vent.
 The only anger I see here is from you and Archie.
 
 

 Do you do so by taking it out on people who don't share your beliefs? 

 No one is taking anything out on anyone. This is a free expression of ideas.
 
 
You say there are evil people among religion? As if there are no evil people among atheists? 

 Of course atheists may also be evil.
 
 

 
 What is wrong with faith in heaven? Your intent is only to put down others. 

 You are repeating yourself.
 
 
You look down on us, you say our faith is blind, but why? 

 I would not hope to "look down" on anyone, least of all someone on an internet forum that I do not know. There is no "US" ethmi, only a "YOU" and you make stupid remarks. It is those remarks that get criticized. 
 Are you actually defending "blind faith"?
 
 I
f a guy has cancer, but has faith that he'll survive, I don't think you'd bash him, saying he has blind faith. So why do you bash us? What's the point? 

 Blind faith is always stupid. I think someone who is dying should have all the facts. There are many decisions to make. One should weigh the likelihood of future events and act accordingly. If someone cannot handle the facts, then maybe unrealistic hope may make them feel better. However, if one completely dismisses the facts and doesn't make the proper preparations for death for himself and his family, criticism of that behavior is warranted. 
 
 Not sure how a this relates to religion.
 
 You seem to be missing the point. 
 I can't speak for anyone else here, but I think it is harmful to have a taboo against questioning religious beliefs. I think that faith itself is harmful (as defined above, which is utterly distinct from trust and hope). I think that a great deal of harm comes to the world by rigid, intransigent religious ideas such as get expressed by you.

Dear Anti-Religion People
 What do you hope to accomplish by bashing religion?

 Are we back to you defining "bash" by proclaiming anybody who doesn't agree with your religion is "bashing" it?
 
 Quite frankly, some religious people are WAYYYY too quick to take offense, claiming "bashing" where none exists.
 This passive aggressive junk may play to a select few, but overall it just gets old and boring.
 
 
 
What constructive activity do you hope to do by getting on here and saying how wrong religion is?

 Advancement of a more moral society?
 The bible has no problem with slavery, and actually endorses misogyny. Two examples our society has evolved from.
 Religion also (for the most part) seems to have evolved to the point of tolerating other religions as well.
 
 But there is still room for improvement, and that won't occur without some analysis. And there will be criticism.
 
 Perhaps a better question is what do you hope to do by getting on here and saying how right your religion is?
 
 
 
Doesn't the first amendment matter anymore? Why do you say we're evil? What is wrong with belief? What is wrong with faith in heaven? Your intent is only to put down others.

 And out parade the strawman arguments.
 1) Disagreement and opposing view-points are NOT first amendment violations. For the most part, we agree in "freedom of speech" around here.
 Who the heck are you talking to with that accusation?
 
 There are some who think it isn't proper when it comes to freely talking about "gay" subjects, or books that have a "gay" theme, but I think that's a problem on YOUR side of the fence. Not ours...
 
 2) "evil"?
 Who the heck are you talking to with that accusation?
 
 3) Nothing is wrong with belief.
 Who the heck are you talking to with that accusation?
 
 4) Nothing is wrong with faith in heaven.
 Who the heck are you talking to with that accusation?
 
 
 
Why do you think you're being smart just by implying that God is evil? Do you think it's funny? Do you need a way to vent your anger? Do you do so by taking it out on people who don't share your beliefs?

 I have to chuckle at this complaint. Purely passive aggressive, while avoiding the actual merits of the argument.
 
 If we had a country leader today who acted half as bad as the Old Testament biblical God, or who promised torture to people who "didn't believe" in him, we would rightfully recognize this country leader as "evil".
 But when it comes to your God, there is a pretense that he must be ASSUMED to be good, and any evidence to the contrary is ignored. Or else we should it is an "unknowable will and wisdom" of God.
 
 As long as you insist that your God must be presumed "good" without question, I really don't see how you can level the complaint you just made.
 
 
 
You say there are evil people among religion? As if there are no evil people among atheists? What is wrong with faith in heaven? Your intent is only to put down others.

 Again, who the heck are you talking to with all these inane accusations?
 
 
 
You look down on us, you say our faith is blind, but why? If a guy has cancer, but has faith that he'll survive, I don't think you'd bash him, saying he has blind faith. So why do you bash us? What's the point?

 Quite frankly, I don't care what you personally believe in your own life.
 It's when people presume to espouse those beliefs, and enforce those beliefs, upon others that I take exception.
 
 And you should be willing to accept the fact that while you have the right to praise your belief, others have a right to criticize it.
 Freedom of speech is a two-way street.
 And if you can't take the heat, maybe you should consider what your worth is in being in the kitchen...

 Speaking personally as an atheist, albeit an agnostic one, I don't heedlessly 'bash' religion at all. I point out logical flaws/consequences, but any belief system that cannot hold it's own against those (even with a simple plea to ineffability) isn't held strongly enough that the owner should be offended by that.
 I debate religion because a) I enjoy the mental exercise, expanding my ideas about the world and trying to see things from the other point of view. b) Some forms of religion (much fundamentalist thinking, IMO) is harmful to other people - especially YEC, which seems to have brainwashed far too many young minds. c) I recognise that I don't know everything. On the grand scale of things, I practically know nothing. Any knowledge that helps me better perceive the world is therefore welcome, regardless of it's source.
Jo Bennett

I'm not sure about other countries, but in the U.S. christian bashing has a long tradition. It has gone on as long as there have been European settlers in North America. The Pilgrims, who were Puritans who founded the Congregationalist Churches, bashed every other religion. They banned, banished, and sometimes killed anyone who disagreed with their religion. Any other religion, of course, came from the devil himself. That included Anglicans, Anabaptists, Baptists, Methodists, Presbyterians, Quackers, Roman Catholics and others. And, of course, the favors were returned without exception. Of course the scale of violence in North America never reached that of Europe, where christian bashing (of other sects) broke out in war. Even in England there were at least two civil wars fought in an effort by one christian sect to bash another. They all considered themselves the one true religion. In the mid 1700s the efforts of the Anglican church to depose Congregationalism as the established religion in the New England colonies was very bitter. There was lots of very creative christian bashing by both sides. In New York, the Anglican church tried to establish a state supported university that was Anglican and meant for the preparation of Anglican ministers, just as Harvard and Yale were Congregationalist universities and William and Mary was an Anglican university. All of this christian bashing tired the people to the extent that the antidisestablishment movement became very popular. As a result, the new Constitutions written by the States in 1776 and 1777 did not establish state religions in many colonies. Finally, continued christian bashing by other christians led to the disestablishment of christian religions in all States, ending with Congregationalism as the state religion in Connecticut in the early 1818, and the repeal of preferential laws in Massachusetts in 1833.
 
 Even on this board you can see Jim carrying on a long and honored christian tradition.

 1) I think Christianity DOES have value.
 The whole "do unto others as you would have them do unto you"? Incredible philosophy.
 And also a LOT of focus on loving other people, INCLUDING your enemies. Pretty potent stuff.
 
 I think it's a little naive in some ways. The "turn the other cheek" thing and "He who lives by the sword shall die by the sword" seem a little too meek, but that's Jesus's focus.
 
 2) Regarding "bigotry", I've got a simple standard.
 You can have whatever opinion you want. I don't care.
 It's when a person wants to take that opinion and ENFORCE it against others, like in discriminating against others, that I see "bigotry".
 
 So, if you think homosexuality "has no value", that's your opinion.
 If you think homosexuals should be discriminated against, in my book that's bigotry.
 
 I would welcome a discussion on such a standard, if you disagree, but I doubt you're up for it.
